Despite a lower metacritic ranking, Long Live the Queen is the kind of game that is just plain fun. I wouldn't get it at full price, but it's worth picking up at a discount or as part of a bundle.  Elodie is the soon-to-be Queen of Nova, and with that comes wars, rebellions, politics, and magic jam-packed into a visual novel. The decisions you make in how to train her, as well as how you behave in conversation, shape how the game turns out and whether she survives to her coronation. If you're looking for grand strategy, this is the wrong game - Long Live the Queen is more about enjoying the story and making decisions rather than using foresight and presence of mind to 'win'.  Despite being a game so heavy in decision making, the biggest complaint is these choices (almost all of which have skill checks associated with them) come with no warning, and a bad choice is sometimes instant-death. Which skills become handy is anything but obvious. For instance, my magic-heavy Princess could not complete the game the first time because I was short on either the decoration or the swords skill. I mean really, I couldn't finish the game because my ability to decorate wasn't high enough? There are also a lot of skills that go unused depending on choices, but there's little one can do about it because, again, the game gives little warning about these events and what is necessary to complete them. That being said, there is also a great level of satisfaction to correctly anticipating danger - who thought court manners and composure could save your life?  However, with proper use of save files, you can greatly reduce the stress of the game and have a lot more fun with it without worrying about starting all over again. As well, I recommend a second/third playthrough using the debug console to set your skills where you want them just so you can see the kinds of choices available and focus purely on the story.  As for the story, there are perhaps too many characters coming in and out. Elodie is a well established character, but everyone else seems to flit in and out of existence. Some characters such as her mage mentor and father make regular appearances, but not her supposed best friend, any suitors chosen, or any of the massive slew of lords and ladies. That being said, Elodie is adorable, and it's hard not to like her. She can be lighthearted or ruthless, as one's skills selections and choices will fling her in all directions of the personality spectrum.  If you've ever played 'Magical Diary', Long Live the Queen is in a similar vein - it's a visual novel with a plethora of possible outcomes dictated by the choices you make in-game. Unlike Magical Diary however, Long Live the Queen is almost merciless in how it treats its titular character, which is odd given it's almost too feminine nature. Nevertheless, despite all criticisms, it's a good bit of fun, though I would recommend looking elsewhere for something more 'serious'.

This game is amazing and well worth the price. Get it. Now.

What is Long Live The Queen? - A text-based choose-your-own-adventure style RPG.  What I liked about Long Live The Queen: - Decently-long (1-2hr) branching story with many different possible endings. - Large number of interesting skills which affect the story in surprising ways. - Mood-management system adds satisfying level of complexity to training via boosts and negative modifiers. - Visual feedback system for skillchecks helps hint at storyline branches and missed opportunities, ehancing replayability.  What I didn't like about Long Live The Queen: - Game events proceed in the same sequence each time and only branch based on player actions - more randomization might have been fun. - Hidden skillcheck levels and complex multi-tier skillchecks for certain encounters leads to a lot of trial-and-error to find successful combinations. - The precise effects of the mood system on the skills bonuses must either be learned by trial-and-error or through the help of a third-party wiki/guide. - Art and sound assets are fairly limited - a few characters do not even have profile pictures. - The character art is highly anime-stylized - it would have been nice to see a wider range of facial characteristics to help differentiate characters from one another.  Overall: I enjoyed the game enough to play it through several times. At first it felt fun to try different skill combinations and choose different story paths. However, eventually trial-and-error tedium took away some of the fun and I found myself resorting to using a wiki to figure out how to get the results I wanted. It would have been nice if the game gave the player more information, such as the skill levels required to pass certain checks and the precise effects of different moods. As a budget title this game is worthwhile, but be warned that it can also be frustrating.

A most wonderful and intriguing game with a deceptively simple gameplay which in truth hids an ingenious and subtle strategic challenge. The player is required to prepare the main character so as to have her, the princess, survive through all the dangers lying between her and the day of her coronation. The challenge lies in the fact that such dangers are various, hidden or sudden and even the most scrupolous and rigid princess trainer can meet failure by the hands of dirty underhanded traps. This is to add to a scripted plot which will have you face a great variety of situations which will spell doom for those who will simple and single mindedly specialise too much only in certain education branches. Every situation, every trap that lies ahead, requires planning to get through and one must be ready to make sacrifices or to be flexibile along the way so as not to perish. The first run of the game is the most fun and bloody and frustrating of course, with the player discovering the scripted plot and its dangers little by little, but it is the most satisfaying too, due to the sheer joy one feels when (though it would be better to say IF) beating the game and finally reaching the coronation ceremony - it doesn't matter how, if by civil war bloodshed or by enforcing your royal divine right through magic or both, you will just feel relieved and super badass for playing it right. Subsequent runs of the game keep being entertaining due to the amazing number of combinations of choices to explore so as to unblock all achievements and unveil all the hidden subplots of the game, which I found really well crafted and enjoyable.  In conclusion, the pretty girly graphic is but a cover for a truly magnificent and genial gloomy, grim plot worth of the best fantasy books. The setting itself is pretty solid too and one cannot but marvel at such a precious gem this unfortunately pretty unknown game turns to be.  Last but not least, a note of caution and a piece of advice for new players: beware whom you trust.

I think this game is probably best played by the sort of people who meticulously & lovingly craft their ideal Pokemon team by breeding multiple generations of them & keeping track of all of the stats & traits & numbers & figures &etc. instead of just, y'know, blazing ahead with the first five things they catch.  If you, like me, are not one of those meticulous craftspersons (you will know this because you somehow always had a Pidgeotto on your team to fight the Elite Four, for no reason other than that you caught it near Pallet Town & just sort of hung onto it), you'll probably love fumbling your way through this game into different, wildly amusing death scenarios. It's a lot of fun! But once you get serious about making Elodie live to become queen-- or, at least, to survive the forest adventure, just that one time-- do yourself a favor by finding the wiki & taking a ton of notes.   Beating this game requires a certain level of precision on the part of the player not usually enjoyed by those who like running around and bashing things with a sword. If you are a thing basher, please, learn from my mistakes. Save yourself inevitable hours of headache & frustration by taking notes.

When I purchased this game with other titles in a Humble Bundle, I didn't exactly know what I was getting into. In fact, this game had me so curious of what it was that I decided to play it first out of all the games I'd purchased.  I can honestly say I never expected this game to be so addicting. It's a visual novel with an excellent story to tell in many different ways. The ways to play are practically limitless. This is one of those interesting pick-up games that you never expect to like until its got to dragged into an addiction to see what would happen next if you changed something as small as how you handled one situation. (The difference between life and death in one choice)  The visuals are pretty, the writing is excellent, and the overall gameplay is engaging. I'd recommend to anyone who enjoys a good, changing story; or just anyone who's looking for something casual to play.

Uh. . . The Queen didn't live very long. . . Anyways. This game is pretty fun. You could say it's a management game in away, in the sense that you manage the protag's skills, mood, and decisions you make as Queen-to-be.  Basically you're sent back home to the castle and you have to start taking private lessons with your tutors to increase your skills in things like your knowledge of Medicine, Economy, Military, Faith, Royal Demeanor, Conversation, Expression, Animal Handling, Weapons, Athletics, History, and Intrigue. All of those are just the categories, there's like three sub-categories you can choose within each of those, so you kind of have to experiment what you think would be more useful before something happens; which is why it's nice they give you more than enough saves.   The significance of those skills is that if you have one of them high enough you can make decisions or it'll help you decide on what decision to make before something happens. It'll also make your situation better, like I maxed out my Military skills (Strategy, Naval Strategy, and Logistics) and I won a civil, pretty straightforward.  Then there's the mood system, where it adds a bonus when taking a class of a certain category, which just means you get more skill points in said class. Each mood has a set of bonus categories and a penalty to others. The penalty just does the opposite of what the bonus does, meaning you don't gain as many skill points in that category as much as you would normally if there wasn't a penalty  If you train a skill category far enough, you'll get an outfit; which boosts that category you got the outfit from. It adds some skill points when equipped, not too much but it can help.  The story, I'll leave that to the individual to decide. Eveyone has different likes and dislikes about things and I figure my opinion on such wouldn't hold much weight.  If you do buy this game, prepare to make mistakes and die a lot. You'd probably have to be pretty carefully about what skills you train to not die.   (feel free to correct me if I said something wrong)

Long Live the Queen is a charming little game about training your recently orphaned princess in the basic facts of life... Namely, you live or you die.  Through lessons on military strategy, history, diplomacy, charm, advanced negotiation tactics, and a myriad of other subjects, you can seek to fortify your princess against the powers that wish to see her demise. But no matter how carefully you plan, you'll learn most from lots and lots of trial and error... RE: Lots and lots of strange & unusual deaths.  Choosing what subjects to emphasize in the training of your princess will allow you to live to see another day, or bring you to an unseemly end with a volley full of arrows, a rejected proposal, or even a box of chocolates.  Everyone seeks to control you. Most everyone wants you dead. Your father is totally useless (naturally).  The verdict: If you enjoy the cutesy anime art style and the many humorous ways in which your little pink princess can meet her maker, give it a go! The painstaking planning of her lessons the game requires to keep her on the throne and out of the grave is enough of a challenge to make even the most patient of gamers rage quit after the 100th death-by-ridiculousness in a row, but if you're in it for the adorably morbid fun, I think you'll be more than satisfied.  Good luck, and watch out for the chocolate. It gets me every time.

Nice idea, well implemented, fun story, nice interaction between mood and training, but in the end the clearest example I've ever seen of 'Do it again, Stupid' gameplay.  You play the game until you die or reach a point where you fail in something you consider interesting. You then load back several saves, or restart, trying to add the training necessary to pass the check you couldn't pass. You reach that check again. Maybe you didn't train enough; try again. Maybe it's immediately followed by a *second* check you didn't know about; try again. Maybe you erred in your new training schedule, or choose a wrong weekend activity and throw your mood off far enough that your training speed is suboptimal, and you die to some check half-way there because you hadn't trained *its* compulsory skill far enough; try again. Maybe you trained *too much*, and now you don't have enough time to train to meet some future thread you don't even know about. Maybe there are two different skills you could train to get past this this point, and you chose the one which depends on other skills which turn out to be useless; try again. Maybe this thing looks interesting (or critical) but isn't *actually* critical and there isn't enough slack in your training schedule to allow training; try again.  I might finish this over the holiday season, but it'll be by maintaining a spreadsheet in a second window and iteratively refining a training and activity schedule over and over again. Or just reading more spoilers than I'm interested in reading for a game of this sort. AAAARGH!

When I first discovered that game, I had no intention of buying it. Luckily, there was a sale a few days later so I gave it a try. And oh boy, I was not disappointed. The first few hours were nothing but trial and error, however, after a few deaths I managed to survive until my coronation. From then on, it was nothing but exploration. And this is exactly what makes this a strong game. It allows you to train various skills which may unlock new paths. The pace at which you learn these skills is influenced by the mood of our heroine, said mood can be achieved by your actions and your weekend activities. Moreover, you can change Elodie's clothes and this is NOT only for fanservice, as those costumes yield benefits for your chosen skills. Combine this with the freedom of choice (in some cases you need specific skills to actually HAVE a choice) and a world full of plot twists, intrigues, alliances, sea monsters, civil wars, poisoned chocolates and several pink, fluffy, chubby deaths await you.  PROS + Lots of choices + Dozens of more or less usefull skills for your crown princess + Mood system allows for specific 'archetypes' + Different ways to beat the game, thus different endings + Some kind of morale system, allowing you to either be a merciful queen or a tyrannical overlord + Quite cute, if you like the manga style + Release the kraken  CONS - Heavily based on trial and error, especially at the beginning - Some achievements are really hard to get (although saving on a regular basis and taking notes will help) - Relatively short (I managed to get all endings and achievements after ~ 20 h)  Still, I defenitely recommend this game due to its many paths and secrets, the artwork and the fun I had watching my princess getting killed over and over again.  08/10
